CARE works in partnership with the Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists of Canada (SOGC), the Association of Gynecologists and Obstetricians of Tanzania (Agota), the Canadian Society for International Health (CSIH), and McGill University’s Institute for Health & Social Policy. The Government of Canada provides funding for the project.

The project implementation activities have been happening in phases (two districts at a time) with the aim of promoting women’s economic empowerment and improving both the quality of reproductive, maternal, newborn health services available, and women and girls' access to health care in the region. The project team works closely with regional and district level health officials to effectively plan for, and deliver respectful and skilled reproductive health care, improve the skills of health care workers to effectively manage labour and delivery, and support communities to address local barriers that impede access to health care, especially for women and girls.

Ifakara Health Institute is an independent evaluator of the program implementation activities. The evaluation goal is to assess if the program has resulted into improved quality and utilization of reproductive, maternal, and new-born health care using a series of cross-sectional households’ surveys after each round of program implementation activities.

The baseline data collection was done in 2017. Follow up rounds of data collection were done in 2018 and 2019. The last round of data collection are planned for January and February 2021. #

fields.title: COMMEMORATION: We celebrate the tremendous efforts by Ifakara women
fields.caption: Some brave Ifakara women. PHOTO | IFAKARA/ComsFILE
fields.description:
Ifakara Health Institute celebrates the tremendous efforts by Ifakara women on the International Women’s Day (IWD) today. The central message for this year is “Women in leadership: Achieving an equal future in a COVID-19 world,” which celebrates efforts by women and girls around the world in shaping a more equal future and recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic and highlights the gaps that remain.

IWD 2021 Campaign Theme

The IWD 2021 campaign theme is: #ChooseToChallenge. A challenged world is an alert world. We can all choose to challenge and call out gender bias and inequality. From challenge comes change. Learn more about the IWD 2021 campaign here.

#IWD2021 #GenerationEquality.

High Level Statements

Ifakara Health Institute Cheif Executive Director

In his official statement to staff, partners and the public on the International Women's Day, IHI Chief Executive Director, Dr. Honorati Masanja expressed commitment to continue challenging inequality. "We believe in gender equity that’s why we’ve been working hard to ensure that women get an equal future they deserve in their career. Download to read the statement.

Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, the UN Women Executive Director

In her statement on the International Women’s Day 2021, Phumzile Mlambo-Ngcuka, the UN Women Executive Director, says this year's commemorations are a  perfect moment to fight for transformative action and to salute women and young people for their relentless drive for gender equality and human rights despite the fact that they come at a difficult time for the world and for gender equality due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Read the full statement here.

 

Generation Equality Forum

This year, the IWD is a rallying cry for Generation Equality, to act for an equal future for all. The Generation Equality Forum, the most important convening for gender equality investment and actions, kicks off in Mexico City from 29 – 31 March, and culminates in Paris in June 2021. It will draw leaders, visionaries, and activists from around the world, safely on a virtual platform, to push for transformative and lasting change for generations to come. Learn more about the Generation Equality Forum, meet the activists, and get inspired by stories of women leaders we admire.

About the IWD

International Women's Day is a global day celebrating the social, economic, cultural and political achievements of women. The day also marks a call to action for accelerating gender parity. Significant activity is witnessed worldwide as groups come together to celebrate women's achievements or rally for women's equality. Learn more here.

Happy International Women’s Day 2021!

fields.title: WORLD TB DAY: Ifakara project launches website for sharing information with stakeholders
fields.caption: The TB-CAPT landing page snip. GRAPHIC | IFAKARA/Coms
fields.description:
On the World TB Day today, Ifakara Health Institute’s TB-CAPT (Close the gap, increase Access, Provide adequate Therapy) project has unveiled today a new website for sharing information about their activities. The website goes by the address: www.tb-capt.org.

TB-CAPT Principal Investigator, Dr. Jerry Hella, emailed the Ifakara Chief Executive Director Dr. Honorati Masanja and the Office of Communication informing about the launching of the website today – which is just in time for the international TB day.

“IHI is within a consortium dubbed as TB-CAPT funded by EDCTP -- we have two trials planned to start this year in Dar es Salaam/Bagamoyo and at Ifakara. This consortium has launched a new website today,” he briefly informs.

Apart from the landing (home) page, the website has five other main pages. On the landing page, it provides information about the project, activities, team members, funding partners and news. Also, there are links to useful resources such as the project’s fact sheet.

About the Consortium and TB-CAPT Project

Ifakara is part of a twelve-member consortium led by the Foundation for Innovative New Diagnostics (FIND) which will conduct clinical trials to provide evidence for impactful implementation of tuberculosis (TB) and TB/HIV co-infection diagnostic strategies in three African countries.

The consortium has put together the TB-CAPT project to run a series of trials that will take place in intended settings of use in Tanzania, Mozambique and South Africa.

Efforts to address the TB epidemic often stumble due to a lack of high-quality diagnostic tests that can be used at community levels or in remote areas. The TB-CAPT consortium includes world-leading institutions that are perfectly placed to evaluate new technologies with the potential to close these gaps so that every person with TB can know their status and access the care they need.

“TB-CAPT will generate evidence to inform the impactful implementation of TB and TB/HIV co-infection diagnostic strategies including drug-susceptibility testing (DST) at the point of care (POC),” the consortium reports in their official website for the project information launched on March 24, 2021.

About the World TB Day

Each year, the World Tuberculosis (TB) Day is commemorated on March 24 to raise public awareness about the devastating health, social and economic consequences of TB, and to step up efforts to end the global TB epidemic. The date marks the day in 1882 when Dr Robert Koch announced that he had discovered the bacterium that causes TB, which opened the way towards diagnosing and curing this disease.

More about World TB Day 2021.

Learn more about the project here: Facilitating implementation of TB testing: The TB-CAPT (Close the gap, increase Access, Provide adequate Therapy).

To learn even more about the project: Check out their website.

#ifakaraevents #ifakararesearch

fields.title: ENGAGEMENT: Bagamoyo DC visits Ifakara offices, research platforms
fields.caption: Bagamoyo District Commissioner, Ms. Zainab Kawawa. PHOTO | FILE
fields.description:
Bagamoyo District Commissioner, Ms. Zainab Kawawa, today visits Ifakara Health Institute offices and research platforms based in Bagamoyo, Coast region, in a half-day familiarization tour.

The research infrastructure she is scheduled to visit are: the Bagamoyo Laboratory, the TB Clinic, the Clinical Trials Facility, the Vector Control Product Testing facilities, and the Training Center at Kingani on the outskirts of Bagamoyo.

Since 2006, IHI and Bagamoyo District Council has been working very closely in improving the health and wellbeing of people through various health projects at the District Hospital, dispensaries and health centers across the district being part of implementation of a 15-year memorandum signed over a decade ago. #

#ifakaranews #ifakaraengages

fields.headline: One-health lab specialist with background in molecular biology
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Mkali joined the Institute in November 2011 fresh from university. She now holds an MSc degree in Molecular Biology from Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB) and did her research on HIV immunotherapy at the Institute of Tropical Medicine, Antwerp in Belgium where she completed studies in 2016. Previously, she was trained in Biotechnology and Laboratory sciences (BSc degree) at Sokoine University of Agriculture in Morogoro, Tanzania and graduated in 2011.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Mkali began her career in research in 2011 as a research officer (laboratory) and since then she has participated in different clinical research activities in Tanzania. She has skills and extensive experience in molecular biology including DNA and RNA extraction, Conventional and Real-time PCR; immuno techniques including ELISA, PBMC isolation, T-cell purification, Flow cytometry and in-vitro parasite and cell culturing. She can work conveniently with different units such as Haematology and Biochemistry. She also possesses essential skills on bioinformatics and whole genome sequencing. Research Areas.

Her research interests include: infectious diseases in particular development of molecular diagnostics since they are rapid and with very high sensitivity; drug resistance monitoring tools and assessing human immune responses to seek for better interventions like vaccines.

Currently, Ms. Mkali is working with the PREDICT project which is part of the USAID’s Emerging Pandemic Threats (EPT) Program, focused on building a global surveillance to detect and prevent the spillover of pathogens of pandemic potential that can move between animals and humans.

In the past, she has been involved in the Non-Malaria Fever project funded by CDC, MiPPAD (Malaria in Pregnancy Preventive Alternative Drugs) in collaboration with CRESIB, the In-vitro Malaria drug resistance project funded by CDC and Malaria Transmission in Tanzania in collaboration with Walter Reed Army-USA.
fields.description: Ms. Happy Mkali is a molecular biologist and one-health laboratory specialist working within the Interventions and Clinical Trials Department. She has a background in biotechnology and molecular biology with over seven-year experience in health research. She has major interests in infectious diseases and has worked in the fields of HIV/AIDS, Malaria and One-Health. She holds an MSc degree in Molecular Biology.

fields.headline: Receptionist who started career as volunteer
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Ndahagalikiye joined the IHI team in 2009 as a volunteer serving in the Administration Unit. In 2010, she was officially employed as Receptionist for Ifakara Branch where she still works in the same position. She attended Primary School Education at Mbande in Dar es Salaam in 1998 and afterwards, she obtained her Certificate of Secondary Education from Forest Hill in Morogoro Region in 2003.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills: After completing her secondary education, she joined the Vocational Education and Training Authority (Veta) in 2004 for technical training, and in 2006, she joined Msimbazi Centre in Dar es Salaam for her Certificate in Secretarial Course. She graduated in 2007. Since 2010, Agnes has been working as Receptionist for the IHI Ifakara Branch
fields.description: Ms. Agnes Eliya Ndahagalikiye sits in the Front Desk at our Ifakara Branch. She has over 10-year work experience in administration. She holds a Secretarial certificate.

fields.headline: Multilingual epidemiologist with background in biostatistics
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Bajaria is people-oriented and has experience of living and working in diverse environments. Shraddha holds a MPH degree from Boston University School of Public Health and a BSc in Biological Sciences from Saint Michael’s College, VT USA.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Bajaria has a background in field research, data collection, management and analysis. She has gained hands-on field experience during a research project in Kenya; looking at health seeking behaviors of the Maasai community. She was also a part of cross-sectional study done in India, which examined the effects of tobacco consumption on prevalence of hypertension. Her skills include use of R and Stata statistical programs.

Ms. Bajaria is currently involved in a USAID funded Kizazi Kipya project as a research scientist. Led by Pact and a collaboration with other partners, the project aims to improve the lives of orphans, vulnerable children and youth in Tanzania, especially those affected by HIV. The project provides multi-sectoral health and social services to eligible children and their caregivers in most regions of Tanzania. Shraddha is actively involved in the research components of the project, using the monitoring data collected to track progress and analyze the effect of implementation.
fields.description: Ms. Shraddha Nailesh Bajaria is a multilingual public health professional working in the Kizazi Kipya project at IHI. She has a background in epidemiology, biostatistics and global health. She holds a Master of Public Health (MPH). Her interests lie in epidemiology of infectious as well as communicable diseases, especially in developing countries.

fields.headline: IHI accounts officer since 2016
fields.background_and_education:
Mr. Hassan Kayera is an IHI employee since January 2016. He completed his primary education at Mlimani in 2003; secondary education at Kenton in 2007 and advanced level of secondary education at Benjamin Mkapa in 2010. Then, he joined University of Arusha for business and accounting studies (2010-2013) and Post Graduate Diploma in Education (Teaching business studies) from Open University of Tanzania (2015).

After completing his studies in 2015, he volunteered at IHI’s Ifakara Branch from July to Dec 2015 before he was transferred to the IHI Bagamoyo Branch where he served as Branch Accountant from January 2016 to February 2018. He was then transferred to the IHI Dar es Salaam Office to serve as Imprest Accountant. Again, in September 2018, he was transferred to the Projects Management Unit to serve as Project Accountant where he is still serving to date. Currently, Mr. Kayera is pursuing a Certified Public Accountant (CPA) accreditation.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Kayera started his career as a volunteer in 2015 before he was formally employed as Assistant Accountant in 2016. He has extensive experience in various accounting packages and can conveniently browse the internet, key in text, use Microsoft office applications, troubleshoot (repair and maintain) computers, and management conflicts.

Previously, before joining IHI he worked at Mobistock Company as Assistant Accountant and Admin officer for one year and Leimart Investment company in the same position and for the same duration. Projects. When Mr. Rajabu joined IHI in January 2010, he started off as an Ines project driver where he served for three years. He was then transferred to the Transport Unit at the Dar es Salaam Office where he has been serving from 2014 to date.
fields.description: Mr. Hassan Kayera serves in the Finance and Accounting Unit as Accountant. He has four-year experience in accounting, two of which he gained at IHI. Mr. Kayera holds a Bachelor degree in Business Administration with Accounting and Management from the University of Arusha he obtained in 2013.

fields.headline: Certified public accountant serving as Deputy Finance Manager
fields.background_and_education: Mr. Lwila was originally trained at Korogwe Teachers’ Training College in Tanzania as a secondary school Mathematics teacher. He then practiced teaching (from 2006-2011) before crossing over to the finance and accounting field after acquiring the Advanced Diploma in Accountancy from the Institute of Accountancy Arusha (IAA) in 2011. He’s already certified as public accountant (CPA) by the National Board of Accountants and Auditors in Tanzania. Mr. Lwila joined IHI in 2011.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Lwila has attended several grants management courses. He has been trained to manage and audit European Commission funded grants under Horizon 2020 (H2020) program. After joining IHI in 2011, his first post was Assistant Internal Auditor which he served for one month before he was moved to the Projects Accounting Unit.

Olove previously worked as a project accountant where he managed grants funded by various funding partners, including; The Global Fund, USAID and CDC, EU and EDCTP, BMGF, and NUFFIC. As Head of the Projects Accounting Unit, the position he assumed in 2013 and held it for 7 years until 2020, he worked with the IHI Grants and Contracts office on budgeting and contracts negotiations.

In his current role as Deputy Finance Manager, Mr. Lwila assists the Finance Manager in the management of finance and accounts operations. Specifically, he is involved in the management of treasury and accounts payable unit; system support and accounting; and project accounting unit.
fields.description: Mr. Olove Lwila is an accountant who serves as Deputy Finance Manager for the Institute since November 2020. He is a Certified Public Accountant.

fields.headline: Data expert with computer programming knowledge
fields.background_and_education: Mr. Madundo briefly joined IHI in July 2016 through the Internship program and he was attached to the Data Systems Unit. He was formally employed in July 2017 as Assistant Field Officer for the ENAP (Every New-Born Action Plan) project. He holds BSc degree in Data Management from Open University of Tanzania (OUT) he obtained in 2018.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills: Mr. Madundo started his professional career in 2012 when he was working as a data entry clerk. He gained extensive practical and working knowledge in handling of large quantities of financial data using Ms. Excel and preparing weekly financial data reports. He has excellent working knowledge in designing electronic questionnaires using Kobo Toolbox and Magpi, data management and analysis using Ms. Excel and STATA. Additionally, he has practical and working knowledge in computer programming languages such as PHP, HTML5, C#, C++, VISUAL BASIC and MySQL.
fields.description: Mr. David Madundo is Data Assistant cum site supervisor attached to a project known as En-Smiling (Every New-Born Simplified Measurements Integrated Longitudinal Neuro-developmental Growth) where he has been serving since July 2018. He holds a BSc degree in Data Management with five-year experience in research data management.

fields.headline: Data clerk wrth HIV testing and counselling knowledge
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Ngulukila is an IHI employee since 2009. She holds a Primary School Education Certificate she obtained from Yombo Primary School in Dar es Salaam in 1997. She then joined Kilombero Secondary School where she completed her Certificate of Secondary Education.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Ngulukila started her Data Clerk career in 2006 at IHI through the Institute’s volunteer program. In 2009, she was employed as Data Clerk at the CDCI. She also has an experience of entering data in the National AIDS Control Program Database, from which she printed reports for various local authorities.

Additionally, she was trained in HIV Testing and Counselling (HTC) when she served for the National AIDS Control Program. Apart from National AIDS program data entry, Ms. Ngulukila is also experienced with data entry for OpenMRS database which is a research-based platform of the CDCI. #
fields.description: Ms. Agatha Ngulukila is serving in the Chronic Diseases Clinic of Ifakara (CDCI) as Data Clerk. She has over 8-year experience.

fields.headline: Director of Science since 2016
fields.background_and_education: Dr. Okumu was originally trained as a Public Health Officer in the College of Health Sciences at the Moi University in Kenya. Before he obtained a PhD, he successfully attended a Master’s degree program in Applied Parasitology at the University of Nairobi, Kenya, and a second Master’s degree program in Geo-information Science, Earth Observation and Environmental Modeling from Lund University, Sweden.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Dr Okumu is an Associate Professor of Public Health at the University of Witwatersrand, South Africa; a Visiting Researcher at the Federal University of Minas Gerais, Brazil, and a honorary Research Fellow at the Institute of Biodiversity, Animal Health and Comparative Medicine, University of Glasgow, UK.

In addition to studying human-mosquito interactions and developing new techniques to complement existing malaria interventions and accelerate efforts towards elimination, Dr. Okumu has interests in quantitative ecology of residual malaria vectors; mathematical simulations to predict effectiveness of interventions, improved housing for marginalised communities, and prevention of child malnutrition.

Dr Okumu was awarded by the American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene the Young Investigator Award in 2009, a Welcome Trust Intermediate Research Fellowship in Public Health and Tropical Medicine (2014-2019), and most recently, a Howard Hughes-Gates International Research Scholarship (2018-2023).

He is currently a co-chair of the Malaria Eradication Research Agenda consultative group on Tools for Elimination, an Associate Editor of the journal, Parasites & Vectors, and a Co-Chair of the WHO Vector Control Working Group on New Tools for Malaria Vector Control. Dr. Okumu has also participated in various international expert panels on a wide range of subjects including, genetically modified mosquitoes and ivermectin for vector control, and the NEPAD Agency of the African Union’s agenda on biotechnology in Africa.

Dr. Okumu was inducted in 2016 as a Young Affiliate of the African Academy of Sciences. He was also named among the 2016 Top 100 Global Thinkers by the US-based Foreign Policy Magazine. #
fields.description: Dr. Fredros Okumu is the IHI Director of Science. He holds a PhD in Infectious Tropical Diseases from London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine he obtained in 2012. Since 2008, Dr Okumu has been studying human-mosquito interactions and developing new techniques to complement existing malaria interventions and accelerate efforts towards elimination.

fields.headline: Chief Operating Officer since January 2019
fields.background_and_education: He is an MBA graduate from the University of Birmingham, United Kingdom. Before joining IHI, Mr. Mfikwa worked with several renowned international companies and NGOs including CARE International, where he was the Director of Finance. In addition to his experience, Martin attended a number of international on-the-job trainings.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
With more than 15 years of experience in finance and accounting, Mr. Mfikwa oversees the Institute’s budget, implement, and monitor all finance and accounting processes, policies, systems, assets and records. He is also charged with the implementation of the Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system, procurement and stores management.

Mr. Mfikwa is a qualified member of the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA), United Kingdom. He is also a registered member of Tanzania National Board of Accountants and Auditors in the category of Associate Certified Public Accountant. #
fields.description: Mr. Martin Mfikwa is the IHI Chief Operating Officer (COO) who oversees the Institute’s finance, administration and human resources. He is an experienced finance director with the high degree of integrity and very strong accounting and financial management knowledge. He holds an MBA from the University of Birmingham, United Kingdom.

fields.headline: Young molecular biologist, biotechnologist
fields.background_and_education:
Mr. Lazaro joined IHI in September 2016 immediately after completing his BSc in Molecular Biology and Biotechnology studies from the University of Dar es Salaam. Previously, he worked with the Management and Development for Health (MDH) as part of student’s practical training where he mainly worked with the MDH – Temeke Specialized Laboratory in HIV viral load testing and HIV Early Infant Diagnosis.

To strengthen his molecular laboratory analysis skills, he also worked as an Intern at the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA)Tanzania hub in Mikocheni, Dar es Salaam for two months in the molecular laboratory.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Lazaro began his career in research in 2016 as a research officer at IHI and since then he has participated in different WaSH related researches performing both field activities and laboratory quality analyses of potable water and wastewater.

He has skills and extensive experience in laboratory analysis of both biological and environmental samples, grant, manuscript and policy briefs writing, data management and analysis, mapping and geo-spatial analyses using QGIS and is a potential leader. He has experience in research dissemination to wide audience through policy briefs, local and international conferences and prospective social media communicator.

Research Areas. His research interests include: monitoring and evaluation of water and sanitation interventions, surveillance of infectious diseases, urban health, climate change and human health. He is passionate about policy advocacy anchored on scientific evidences. Mr. Lazaro and colleagues have recently submitted a manuscript to Geo-Health Journal with a number in pipeline from their WASH related researches. He has authored 1 internal conference abstract, 1 international conference abstract and co-authored about 3 international conference abstracts.

Projects. Mr. Lazaro has been involved in three IHI projects at since when he joined IHI: The first one aimed at assessing the effectiveness of WaSH interventions against health vulnerabilities associated with climate change in Tanzania. The second of whom he is partially involved aims at monitoring and evaluating the innovative solution for sanitation challenges in urban informal settlements (slums) of urban Dar es Salaam.

He is currently involved in the project aiming at integrating sustainable water and sanitation solutions to create safer, more inclusive and climate resilient cities in Tanzania and South Africa.
fields.description:
Mr. Alfred Boniphace Lazaro is a molecular biologist and biotechnologist working with the water, sanitation and hygiene (WaSH) research group within the Environment Health and Ecological Sciences Department. He has a background in molecular biology and biotechnology with over two-year experience in health research. He holds a BSc and currently a prospective MSc. Student in Medical Microbiology.

His research interests range from monitoring and evaluation of water and sanitation interventions, surveillance of infectious diseases, urban health, climate change and human health as well as national, regional and international policy impacting. He has basic data management skills including data analysis, map and minor geo-spatial analyses using tools such as Excel, ODK, QGIS and R-Studio

fields.headline: Nurse with background in HIV/Aids care and treatment
fields.background_and_education:
Ms. Mrema joined IHI for the first time in April 2011 through the Neovita study as a Research Nurse/Supervisor which involved enrollment and follow up of participants.

Before that, between 2002 to 2011, she served as Research Assistant for the MUCHS/HARVAD Collaboration Research Project which was conducted at Muhimbili National Hospital and HPTN 024-labor Ward (2) child 1 study, and in the year 2018 she rejoined IHI as a Nurse in the Calcium study.

Ms. Mrema successfully attended the Certificate of Pre-Nursing study program at St. Francis Hospital (Ifakara, Morogoro) between 1986-87. Afterwards, from 1988-1992, she attended another program at Mvumi Hospital in Dodoma where she was trained and certified as Midwife Nurse.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Mrema has been providing midwife services in Tanzania for more than 20 years and also involved in several health projects in her carrier, especially on the Training on HIV/Aids Care and Treatment in Tanzania, midwife and nutrition with people living with HIV/Aids. She is also experienced in HIV/Aids counselling, very good in communication skills, documentation and customer care.

Ms. Mrema has participated in a number of health research activities from 2005 to date
fields.description: Ms. Ester Mrema is a licensed Nurse Midwife with 27-year experience in training on HIV/Aids care and treatment, midwife and nutrition for people living with HIV/Aids. Currently, she is attached to the Calcium Supplementation for Pregnant Women study which is being undertaken in Dar es Salaam. In 2012, Ms. Mrema received Appreciation Award for Enrollment staff from Ifakara Health Institute/Harvard School of Public Health.

fields.headline: Admin specialist with background in computerized management systems
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Giteta joined the Institute in March 2018 from Panacea Consulting group where she worked as a Business Administrator from 2016 to 2017. Before that, she worked with Ilala Municipal Council as Business Officer from 2015 to 2016. She holds a Bachelor Degree of Business Administration from University of Iringa where she completed studies in 2014.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Giteta has over 5-year experience in business administration. She has skills and extensive experience in computerize management system. She can work conveniently with different platforms such as Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS). She also possesses ability to analyse issues and provide practical solutions.

When Ms. Giteta joined IHI in March 2018, she started working with URCT Project. She was then transferred to VCPTU projects in November 2018 where she is still working to date
fields.description: Ms. Ester Giteta is an Administrative Officer working with Vector Control Product Testing Unit within the Environmental Health and Ecological Science Department. She has five years experience in Business Administration. She holds a Bachelor Degree in Business Administration.

fields.headline: Field interviewer with over 10-year experience in entomology
fields.background_and_education: Mr. Mwasheshi is an IHI employee since 2008. He holds a Primary School Education Certificate he obtained from Ifakara’s Madukani Primary School in 1998. He then joined Kasita Secondary School where he obtained a certificate of secondary education in 2003. Afterwards, he went to Kasita Seminary for A- level studies from 2004 -2006.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Mwasheshi started his entomology career in 2008 in Ifakara where he was employed as a Field Interviewer.

Projects. Mr. Mwasheshi has worked with several projects like VIDI, VPR, MCD, MIRS, and Funestus 100 and departmental work in general from 2008 to date.
fields.description: Mr. Dickson Mwasheshi is a Field Interviewer serving in the Department of Environmental Health and Ecological Sciences. He has over 10-year experience in working in the Entomology Unit.

fields.headline: Entomology technician since 2013
fields.background_and_education: Mr. Kobe is an IHI employee since 2013. He holds a Primary School Education Certificate he obtained from Mapinga Primary in 2005. He then joined Dunda Secondary School where he studied up to the Form Four level
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Kobe started his career as field work volunteer at TAMASHA in 2011 and joined WAMATA as field worker in the same year. He started serving as entomology technician in the Vector Control Product Testing Unit in 2013.

Projects. Mr. Kobe has served in a number of projects at IHI, including: WHIOES, SRMC, MIN TRIAL, HOLED NET, and ABCDR project.
fields.description: Mr. Dickson Kobe is a technician working with the Vector Control Product Testing Unit in Bagamoyo Branch. He has over 5-year experience in the job.

fields.headline: Vector control product testing supervisor since 2017
fields.background_and_education: Mr. Mbeyela is an IHI employee since 2006. He attended Njombe Secondary School before joining Topseeds Institute of Hotel and Tourism Management in 2016 where he graduated with a Certificate in Basic Computer Application Information Technology. He then joined KIU in 2013.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills: Mr. Mbeyela started his career in 1994 as a Sales Manager for Ifakara Interbusiness. He then joined IHI in 2006 as an entomology technician. In 2016, he was promoted to the position of Insectary Manager and a year later, he was appointed Test Facility Supervisor. He is serving in this post to date. #
fields.description: Mr. Edgar Mbeyela is serving in the Vector Control Product Test Unit within the Environmental Health and Ecological Sciences at our Bagamoyo Branch. He is a Kampala International University (KIU) graduate with a Certificate in Information Technology.

fields.headline: Entomology technician who started career as office attendant
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Ismail joined the Institute in 2012 as Office Attendant. After serving for one year, she was transferred to the Vector Control Product Testing where she is working to date. She holds a Primary School Education Certificate he obtained from Mwambao Primary in 1995. She then joined Taima Secondary School where she studied up to the Form Three level. She was forced to cut her secondary studies short due to family problems.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Ismail started her entomology technician career in 2016 in the Vector Control Product Testing Unit Bagamoyo. Since then, she has been serving at the Bagamoyo Insectary focusing mainly on establishing and maintaining mosquito colonies for product testing.

Previously, before starting her career at IHI, between 2006 and 2007, she studied at Joseph Polytechnic Training where she graduated with a Certificate in Hotel Management.
fields.description: Ms. Chausiku Ismail is a technician with the Vector Control Product Testing Unit in Bagamoyo. She has over 5-year experience in the job

fields.headline: Lab technologist versed with smart immunological techniques
fields.background_and_education:
Officially, Mr. Mtaka joined the Institute in October 2018 as a laboratory technician working in the Malaria Vaccine Trial (VAC070 Study) in the Bagamoyo Lab within the Intervention and Clinical Trials Department.

Before joining the Institute, he served as Intern in the IHI Bagamoyo lab and during his service, he was trained as laboratory technician. He holds a Diploma in laboratory technology he obtained from Sokoine University of Agriculture.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Mtaka started his career at Bagamoyo Research and Training Center as an Intern after completing his Diploma studies and participating in different laboratory activities.

He can perform different immunological techniques, malaria antibody ELISA, intracellular cytokine staining, and ELISPOT assays, together with Pbmc isolation. Also, he has good laboratory skills in performing gene xpert of which he obtained skills during his tenure as Intern at IHI.
fields.description: Mr. Ivanny Mtaka is a Laboratory technician working with the Malaria Vaccine study (VAC 070) within the Interventions and Clinical Trials department at IHI. He holds a Diploma in Laboratory Technology and has two-year experience in the job.

fields.headline: Active nurse since 1970s
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Chale is IHI employee since 2012. She holds a Primary School Education Certificate she obtained from Ilonga Primary School in Kilosa District, Morogoro Region. She then joined Ilonga Girls Secondary for her secondary level of education. After school, she joined Masasi Nursing college in Mtwara where she obtained a certificate in Nursing in 1974.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Chale started her nursing career in 1974 in Kilosa at Ulaya Dispensary as Attending Nurse. Afterward, she joined Kisanga Dispensary and Kilosa Hospital where she served in the same capacity.

Then she moved to Kibaoni Dispensary at Kilombero District as a Nurse-Midwife and then joined St. Francis Hospital where she was employed as Enrolled Nursing Midwife and Translator. She has a lot of experience in nursing, reproductive child health (general) and reproductive child health for family infected with HIV and AIDS.
fields.description: Ms. Adolphina Chale serves in the Chronic Diseases Clinic of Ifakara (CDCI) as Enrolled Nurse Midwifery and Translator. She has over 30-year experience in nursing.

fields.headline: Biostatistician with over ten-year experience in nutrition surveys
fields.background_and_education:
Ms. Kalinjuma joined the Institute in October 2014 from Tanzania Food and Nutrition Centre (TFNC) where she worked as Research Officer (Statistics) under the department of Nutrition Policy and Planning (NPP). She holds an M.Sc. in Statistics (Biostatistics) from Hasselt University in Belgium she obtained in September 2012.

 

Previously, she was trained as a Statistician at University of Dar-es-Salaam, Tanzania where she graduated in 2007. From 2018 to date, Ms. Kalinjuma is currently a postdoctoral research fellow at Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, United States of America.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Kalinjuma began her career in October 2007 as Research Assistant (Statistics) at TFNC where she worked for seven years. She was responsible for nutrition research methodology, data processing and analysis and reporting. Later in October, 2014, she joined IHI as Research Scientist mainly responsible for data management and statistics for the Kilombero and Ulanga Antiretroviral Cohort (KIULARCO) embedded in HIV care and treatment center of St. Francis Referral Hospital at Ifakara, Morogoro, Tanzania. Since then she has participated in various research studies involving KIULARCO database for HIV-infected in rural, Tanzania.   

 

She has skills in data management and statistical analysis for cross-sectional data, longitudinal data, survival data, handling missing data for both cross-sectional and survival data. Further, she is trained on anthropometry measurements for children under five (weight and height), nutrition assessment and surveillance, food and nutrition security monitoring, evaluation and impact assessment, modeling infectious diseases, Service provision assessment survey data analysis. She can work conveniently with various statistical analysis platforms such as Stata, SAS, R and SPSS.

 

Research Areas: Her research interest includes: loss to follow-up among HIV-infected person enrolled in HIV care and treatment center, trends of body mass index in HIV-infected persons on antiretroviral treatment, vitamin D and pregnancy outcomes and placental malaria outcomes in pregnant women. She has co-authored 8 articles in international journals, with major role being data management and/or data analysis. #
fields.description: Ms. Aneth Vedastus Kalinjuma is a biostatistician working with the Chronic Disease Clinic of Ifakara (CDCI) in the Department of Interventions and Clinical Trials. Her background is statistics with over ten-year working experience in nutrition surveys methodology. She holds BA in Statistics and MSc. in Statistics. Her research interests are: HIV, TB infection, nutrition outcomes in children under five years of age and adults; and malaria infection during pregnancy and pregnancy outcomes.

fields.headline: Estate manager with over 30-year experience
fields.background_and_education:
Mr. Lyimo in an IHI employee since 2009. He attended Primary School at Kilimanjaro Shia and graduated in 1984. He then joined West Hai Furniture workshop where he was trained in theory and practice in all kinds of carpentry work.

Mr. Lyimo currently holds a Carpentry & Joinery Certificate from National Vocation Training Center (NVTC) Dar es Salaam where he graduated in 2000. He was forced to join carpentry workshop instead of secondary school due to family problems.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Mr. Lyimo started his carpentry career in 1986 at West Hai Furniture Makers in Kilimanjaro where he was employed as a carpenter & joinery. From 1991-1993, he was at the National Vocational and Training Center (NVTC) - now Vocational Education and Training Center (VETA) – where he studied and graduated as carpenter & joinery grade 1.

From 1993-2000 he operated his own carpentry workshop. From 2001-2004, he joined Swiss Garden Hotel where he was involved in building construction and maintenance. Between 2004 and 2007, he joined the Swiss Lab System GmbH as technical assistant and from 2008-2009, he joined West Hai Furniture Makers as carpentry workshop supervisor.

Projects. When Mr. Lyimo joined IHI in August 2009, he was posted to the IHI Bagamoyo branch – particularly to assist in Kingani and BRTC renovation and building work as assistant estate manager. He stayed there for two years. #
fields.description: Mr. Exaud Lyimo is an assistant estate manager based at our Ifakara branch. He has over 30-year experience in carpenter & joinery. Previously, he served in our Bagamoyo branch, Dar es Salaam office and our Ifakara partner, St. Francis Referral Hospital.

fields.headline: Clinical epidemiologist who previously served as IHI director
fields.background_and_education: Prof. Abdulla holds a PhD in Epidemiology from University of Basel, and a Master of Science in Epidemiology from the London University’s School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. Previously, he was trained as a medical doctor (MD).
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Prof. Abdulla serves as member in various technical and advisory committees at national and international level including co-chairing the Vector Control Advisory Group (VCAG) of the World Health Organisation. He also has interest in the translation of research results into policy, clinical epidemiology and capacity development issues.

Prof. Abdulla has published extensively on malaria and received the centenary medal of the UK Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene and the Donald Reid Medal from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine for contributions in epidemiology and malaria control.
fields.description: Prof. Salim Abdulla is a Clinical Epidemiologist and former Chief Executive Director of the Ifakara Health Institute. His current work focuses on evaluation of new interventions for malaria including diagnostics, insecticide treated nets, drugs and vaccines, conducting field trials from Phase I to Phase IV.  Prof Abdulla leads the malaria and COVID-19 clinical research program at IHI with work in Tanzania and Equatorial Guinea.

fields.headline: Quality Assurance Manager
fields.background_and_education: Request profile to this email: aurassa@ihi.or.tz

fields.headline: Research Scientist
fields.background_and_education:
Dr. Milando joined the Institute in May 2014 as a Research Officer after completing her internship at the Mwanayamala Regional Referral Hospital in Dar es Salaam. Previously, she was trained as a Medical Doctor at the Muhimbili University of Health and Allied Sciences (Muhas), Dar es Salaam, Tanzania and graduated in 2012. 

Dr. Milando pursued a Master of Public Health from the same university and graduated in 2017. During the master’s program, she acquired knowledge and skills for managing public health programs; planning, implementing, monitoring and evaluating public health programs or interventions, as well as designing and conducting public health research. Currently, she is undergoing fellowship training on Global Health Leadership under the Afya Bora Consortium.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Dr. Milando has been participating in the evaluation of pre-erythrocytic and blood-stage malaria vaccines and treatments for regulatory licensure and has over 5-year experience in conducting Phase I to Phase IV Good Clinical Practice (GCP) compliant clinical trials. Her scientific knowledge and clinical expertise cut across the spectrum from the diagnosis, treatment and care to conducting advanced clinical research.

Dr. Milando has been actively involved in the implementation of the clinical trials which test the safety, efficacy and tolerability of malaria vaccine using Controlled Human Malaria Infection (CHMI) of purified Sporozoite. These trials have been conducted successfully with volunteers of varying ages (from 6 months to 45 years), both HIV status, different dose regimes in excellent study designs.

She actively participates in the recruitment of volunteers into clinical trials by participating in initial meetings, performing informed consent process, reviewing the health of the clinical trial subjects and providing clinical judgment on their health status during clinical visits, and completion of case report forms. 

Additionally, Dr. Milando is involved in the writing of clinical trial protocols, standard operational procedures and safety reports as well as review of adverse events occurring during study periods.
fields.description: Dr. Florence Milando is a medical doctor and a public health specialist working with the Malaria Research group within the Interventions and Clinical Trials Department at IHI. She has a background in clinical medicine (MD) with over five-year experience in public healthcare and research. She holds an MD and a Master of Public Health.

fields.headline: Research Scientist
fields.background_and_education: He holds a Master’s degree in Medical Education from Centre for Medical Education, University of Dundee Scotland. He has extensive experience as a practicing clinician and in clinical training. His experience ranges from curriculum design, assessment and teaching methodologies.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
He joined the Institute in 2007 and was instrumental in establishing the Quality Assurance system at Clinical Trial Bagamoyo branch, and Community Advisory Boards at Bagamoyo, Ifakara and Kigoma branches of IHI. He was a study site coordinator for the phase III malaria vaccine trial.

In the community engagement arena, he has been involved in study result dissemination to study participants and policy makers. He has published few papers on malaria vaccine trials, community advisory boards in limited resource setting and community perspective on malaria vaccine. #
fields.description: Dr Kafuruki  Shubis is  currently heading the Training Department and coordinating implementation of the Masters of Science in Public Health Research, a joint program with Nelson Mandela African Institution of Science and technology Arusha campus. He has extensive experience as a practicing clinician and in clinical training.

fields.headline: Certified Public Accountant since 2017
fields.background_and_education: Ms. Mlege joined IHI in November 2007 where she served as Branch Accountant cum Administrator. She acquired an Advance Diploma in Accountancy from the Institute of Finance Management (IFM) in 2001. She then worked with Celtel Tanzania Limited as Accounts Officer up to Jan 2006 when she was promoted as Finance and Administration Manager. In 2017, the National Board of Accounts and Auditors of Tanzania granted her a professional award of Certified Public Accountant (CPA).
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Ms. Mlege has attended several grants management courses. She has been trained to manage and audit European Commission funded grants under Horizon 2020 (H2020) program. After joining IHI in 2007, her first post was Branch Accountant cum Administrator for Bagamoyo Branch where she served for three years before she was moved to the Dar es Salaam office.

Before assuming her current roles, she worked as Project Accountant where she managed grants from various funding partners, including; COMIC Relief, USAID and CDC, EU and EDCTP, BMGF, and PATH.

As Revenue Accountant, the position she assumed in July 2019, Ms. Mlege leads the IHI Finalization of Accounts Section. She also supports Administration and Project Management.
fields.description: Ms. Hadija Njambi Mlege is a Certified Public Accountant who technically supports financial operations of the Institute as Revenue Accountant since 2019. She has over 15 years of experience in handling project and corporate finance. Before July 2019, she served as Project Accountant and Deputy Leader of the Project Accountants Section at IHI.

fields.headline: Research Officer
fields.background_and_education:
Alphonce graduated from the University of Dar es Salaam in 2014 after completing his Bachelor of Science (Major in Zoology with wildlife sciences and conservation). He has previously worked as a High School biology and chemistry teacher in Dar es salaam. He then joined the Ifakara Health Institute in 2017 and has since worked in studying and controlling of Aedes mosquitoes that transmits a variety of arboviruses such as Dengue, Chikungunya and and Zika. He has also worked in studying and controlling of Anopheles mosquitoes that transmits the deadly malaria disease.


.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
His career started in 2017 working as a research officer in the control of Aedes mosquitoes that transmit arthropod-borne viruses such as DENGV, ZIKV and CHIKV. The project was focused on the use of affordable, scalable, low technology transfluthrin emanators against Aedes mosquitoes in Dar es salaam and was funded by the UK Medical and research council (MRC) and USAID.

He has also been a part of the ACOBISREM malaria project funded by Bill & Melinda gates foundation in Rufiji district where he has been working as an entomologist in studying malaria mosquito distribution and behavior in relation to malaria epidemiology. He has also performed insecticide resistance tests to determine insecticide susceptibility status of Aedes mosquitoes. He also has skills in scientific methods of research and biostatistics and can analyze Quantitative data using R statistical software. He is also a one health biologist with expertise in the control of zoonotic and bovine diseases
fields.description: Mr. Alphonce is a zoologist with a predilection for entomology, ecology and one health fields of science. He works as a research officer in the department of environmental health and ecological sciences and has more than four years of research experience in the field of entomology particularly in the control of mosquitoes and mosquito-borne diseases. He also has expertise in the control of endectoparasites and endectoparasitic infections of cattle..

fields.headline: Principal Research Scientist
fields.background_and_education: He joined IHI12 years ago,Dr. Lwetoijera graduated with PhD in Medical Entomology from Liverpool School ofTropical Medicine in 2016.
fields.professional_experience_and_skills:
Dr. Lwetoijera Within his 12 years of experience in malaria vectors control research, he has made notable contribution that include: - 30 peer reviewed publications; participated in institutional fund raising of 4.2 million USD; and reviewed over 28 research manuscripts submitted for publication international peer review journals within 4 years after PhD; An Editorial board member of Frontiers in sustainable cities Journal.

 

Research Areas: His research interest focuses on alternative vector control tools with potential to target mosquitoes outdoors. Specifically, he is focused on autodissemination, a mosquito assisted larviciding; genetic based technologies for mosquito control, innovative solutions for malaria control through house improvement; design surveillance and control platform for managing arboviruses transmitting Aedes mosquitoes in urban settings. Most importantly, he aspires to establish local and international collaboration around these research themes with potential to foster his career growth and catalyse generation of data-driven solutions, building local research capacity and support its integration into national vector control efforts. #
fields.description: Dr.  Dickson Wilson Lwetoijera Is a Medical Entomologist currently saving as Deputy head of Training and Capacity Building Department at (IHI), a Professor at Nelson Mandela African Institute of Science and Technology (NM-AIST), and a Wellcome Trust International Intermediate Fellow (2020-2024).  He holds PhD in Medical Entomology from Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine. He has more than 12 years’ experience in malaria vectors control research.
